div3.head: Stenographers and Photographers.
div3.p: --Proposals will be received by the undersigned until the first day of September next for contracts for making reports of the proceedings and of the Senate of the Confederate State.
The contractor will be required to furnish his own The sessions of the Senate will, it average about six months per annum, about three hours per day
Stationary will be furnished at the expense of the Senate as also a reporters' room for writing out together with lights and fuel.
The contract will be made for one year from the Monday of November next, and a Proberta compensation paid the contractor monthly.
The reports must embrace a verbalism report of all motions, resolutions, remark, speeches, and such amendments offered as may be necessary to the debates.
The committee estimate that the principal reporter and three assistants can perform the work.
The chief reporter and his assistants will be officers of the Senate, and entitled to the privileges and immunities incidental thereto, and removal by the Senate for any want of capacity or fidelity.
A fair copy of the daily reports must be written completion time for the next daily morning papers.
Proposes will be addressed to Jas L Orr, Anderson, South Carolina.

R W Johnson,
A C Brown.

div3.head: To the Clerks of the county Courts.
div3.p:
--In order to brecciate the granting of certificates for exemption from military duty by the Governor, it is desirable to obtain lists of the Justices of the Peace lately elected from the several districts of each county, with the respective ages of the Justices.
The Clerks of Courts are requested to furnish this information as soon as practicable, directed to the Secretary of the Commonwealth.--Justices elect are not entitled to commissions until thirty days after their election, and their term of service will not commence until the 1st of August next.
Certificates for exemption will, therefore, not take effect until after that date.
The Dispatch is sold to News Dealers at twenty Cents per copy.
City Carriers are authorized to charge One Dollar and Fifty Cents per week, to regular subscribers.

div3.head: The War news.
div3.p:
It was reported in Petersburg late Sunday evening that the enemy were burning surplus baggage on their extreme left, and making such movements as gave rise to the impression that they were about to contract their lines by withdrawing from the Southern Railroad, but it was believed on Monday that they were still there in considerable force.
We hear that picket firing has been discontinued, both sides seeming to have come to the conclusion that it is a practice more honored in the breach than in the observance.
The incidents of Monday were of slight importance.
At one o'clock in the afternoon a heavy cannonade opened on our left, and continued for some fifteen minutes, when it ceased entirely and about three o'clock the enemy made an artillery demonstration upon our centre, keeping up a heavy fire for some time.
We have no in formation as to the object sought to be accomplished in either case.
Movements of the enemy's wagon trains, in the vicinity of Battery No, 5, have created the conjecture that they are making some alterations in that work, but what those alterations are no one on our side knows.
A report is in circulation that the enemy have repaired the Norfolk Railroad, and are now operating it to within two or three miles of Petersburg.

It was rumored yesterday that a considerable force of Yankees had been moved over to the north side of James river.
It is stated that the water obtained in Prince George is so impure as to cause great mortality in Grant's army, and that this movement has been resorted to as a sanitary measure.
We only hope that they may every where find the water as bitter as that of the Dead Sea.
If poison were thrown into the wells it would have a beneficial effect, in exterminating the basest set of villains that ever cursed any portion of the earth.

Passengers by the Petersburg train last evening state that everything was unusually quiet yesterday on the Southside.
It was the opinion of some that the armies would have taken advantage of the cooler weather to recommence active hostilities, but we are assured that there has been no material change in the situation.
The belief prevails in some quarters that a great battle cannot much longer be delayed.
Grant is probably holding council with Lincoln, who is reported to have gone to the "front"--(he will doubtless keep as far to the rear as possible)--upon his future plans, and as soon as they are decided upon the grand struggle for supremacy may be inaugurated.
Under the stimulating affects of Grant's whiskey, Old Abe will promise an abundance of men to fill up the gaps created by Confederate bullets, and then the Yankees will be sent into the fight like sheep to the slaughter.

div4.head: Incidents of the defence of Petersburg.
div4.p:
We have been permitted to peruse a letter from a gallant young soldier of this city, a member of Sturdivant's battery, which gives some interesting incidents of the defence of Petersburg, not heretofore noticed in detail.
As it furnishes a connected and reliable history of the earlier events of the contest immediately around that city, and the part borne by a company from Richmond, we give place to some extracts from the letter.

q.p:
On Wednesday, the 15th, we were attacked by Burnside's and Hancock's corps.
To oppose them were about — pieces of artillery and — infantry strung out over a line of fortifications some four miles long.--I was not with our company, but had command of a howitzer worked by infantrymen at Battery No. 8, some five hundred yards to the left of the company.
Capt. Sturdivant commanded all the artillery on that part of the line, and was conspicuous for his coolness and efficiency.

"About 10 o'clock the enemy made his appearance in our front, and in a short time his sharpshooters were at work industriously.
These, however, were several times dislodged, and every attempt at an advance was foiled by the heavy fire of our artillery.--Late in the afternoon the enemy emerged from the woods in line of battle, and advanced swiftly towards Batteries 5, 6 and 7, some four hundred yards to my left.
We very soon concentrated our artillery fire upon them, and they wavered, broke and fell back in confusion.

"Some half an hour later, while shelling sharpshooters from an orchard in front of me, I saw the Yankees in heavy force (fluorines of battle) advancing at a double quick on the same point from which they and before been repulsed.
At this juncture our infantry ammunition gave out, and the ordnance wagon was unfortunately some distance in the rear.
After firing their last round of banister, our artillerists were compelled to fall back from batteries 5, 6, and 7.
At the former Captain Sturdivant was taken.

"All this time I was firing as fast as possible with shrapnel and canister, and Sturdivant's pieces on my right with two-second shell.
Suddenly a force of the enemy appeared immediately in front, and attempted to charge my gun. I gave them canister, and saw the 'stars and stripes' fall to the ground several times.
The enemy at that time were so close that I heard every command their officers gave.
While I was thus engaged in front the enemy had turned our left and gotten inside of our fortifications, compelling the infantry between me and No. 7 to fall back.
Col H rode up to me and said'We shall be obliged to abandon this position.' 'I have no horse.
and must leave the place and spike at replied; 'Very well, do so'' --and he on. While this brief conversation was on, the infantry were falling I told the cannoneers to look out for themselves as best they could, they did instanter.
For want of something better, I cut a wooden plug and spiked the piece.
When I started to retreat the only persons near me were two of the Bluesman a Petersburg militiaman.
We had not fallen back more than seventy-five yards when General Dearing rode up, rallied the infantry, and led us back to No. 8, which we gained just before the Yankees got to it. With the assistance of two infantrymen, I umpired the gun and commenced firing with canister again.
The enemy, however, were too strong for us, and we were again compelled to fall back about four hundred yards, where we made another stand.
Here my part in the fight ended.
Our battery lost two pieces, a good many horses, and fifteen men killed, wounded, and missing."

div4.head: The Danville Railroad.
div4.p:
We have no definite information of the movements of Kautz's raiders since their repulse by Captain Farrinhilt's command.
Although the dispatch of Colonel Withers, announcing this success, was dated at Clover Depot, it is believed that the fight took place at Staunton river bridle, a few miles this side.
The Yankees are understood to have retreated down the and it is ap prehended that they may cross and tap the railroad at some point in Halifax county.

div4.head: More Vandalism.
div4.p: It is currently reported that the Court-house of Nottoway county, and most of the buildings at that point have been burnt by the enemy.

div4.head: A victory in Northern Georgia.
div4.p:
Through the energy of the Signal Corps, the following dispatch from General Joseph E Johnston was received at General Bragg's headquarters yesterday afternoon.
From General Johnston's known modesty in announcing a victory, we are at liberty to inform that our arms in Northern Georgia have achieved a decided success.
Indeed, the news may be regarded as the glad ladings of a glorious victory:

div5.p: The enemy advanced on our whole line to day. They assaulted French, Cheatham, Cleburne, Stevenson and Quarles, by whom they were repulsed.
On the rest of the line the skirmishing was severe.

Their loss in supposed to be great.
Ours is known to be small.

div4.head: From Morgan's command.
div4.p:
We have information from a reliable source that Gen John H Morgan's command has safely arrived in South western Virginia.
All the Yankee accounts of a failure of the expedition and the defeat of Morgan are pure fabrications.
He destroyed a very large amount of property, and captured from 2,500 to 3,000 prisoners, who were released on parole.
His losses, we understand, were comparatively slight.
Captain John Marshall, of Morgan's command, a son of Hon. Humphrey Marshall, of this city, was captured in Kentucky, and is now a prisoner in the hands of the enemy.

div4.head: Hunter's retreat.
div4.p:
Persons living in the upper part of Bedford county report that Hunter's army, on its retreat from Lynchburg, drove through that section at a furious rate, under whip and spur.
The road was lined with dead horses, that had either given up the ghost from over exertion, or, having given out, were killed by their brutal masters.
The enemy manifested unmistakable signs of fright and demoralization, and were hard pressed for provisions.

div3.head: Rapid advance in cold at the North.
div3.p:
We heard late last night that a Northern paper had been received in this city, which gave the quotation of gold in New York on the 25th at 244.
So it goes.
Having passed the magic figure of 250, there is no telling where it will stop.

div3.head: The fight with Hunter's command at Hanging Rock.
div3.p: The Lynchburg Republican, of Sunday, has, from an eye witness, the particulars of the fight with Hunter's troops at Hanging Rock on the Wednesday before;

At Bonsack's Depot the enemy made a clean sweep of almost everything.
The extensive manufacturing establishment of Mr Bonsack was pillaged of a large amount of jeans cloth — about fifteen thousand yards; when the building was set on fire and entirely consumed.
The enemy then made a prisoner of Mr Bonsack, for what reason is unexplained, and carried him off with them.
The depot at this place, as before stated, was also burned, together with several other buildings.
The loss of the Bonsack's mill is a very serious one as the Government was furnished with large supplies of cloth from its looms, while if gave employment to many poor people, mostly women, who are thus thrown on the cold charities of the world for a support.

The friends, however, were made to leave Bonsack's in a rather unceremonious manner, our forces coming close upon them, and so rapid was their retreat from that point to Salem, that they did not tarry to inflict any damage to the railroad, except the burning of the depot at Big Lick — and for the same reason the country along the route suffered very little, in fact, none at all, except that committed by petty thieves and small straggling parties.

On reaching Salem, the enemy determined to continue his retreat to Christiansburg, with the intention of pushing on to the Lead Mines and Salt Works, and in fact, a large portion of his wagon train had been sent forward in that direction, begetting information that Gen Morgan had returned from Kentucky and was at the Salt Works with five thousand men, he changed his course and took the road leading to Newcastle and Sweet Springs.
Hunter, however, had not proceeded on this road but a few miles, when he found that the vigilant Gen McCausland was in his front, and almost before he was aware of it some ten or twelve pieces of his artillery, twenty five or thirty wagons, between two and three hundred prisoners, a number of negroes and about two hundred horses were in the hand of our cavalry.
The enemy, however, quickly threw forward his forces, and compelled Gen McCausiand to abandon all except six of the captured pieces of artillery, but with them and the other captures Gen McC withdrew to the spur of a mountain close by, where he gained a position almost impregnable.
The enemy then attempted to continue his retreat, but from the new position occupied by our forces his trains were rapidly fired into by the captured guns, and, to save them from imaginary capture, the enemy blew up a number of caissons and destroyed a large portion of his train.
Many of the enemy's men were killed by the explodes on of their own caissons, and in the several little skirmishes which occurred, their casualties are reported as being quite heavy.
Our loss was but slight, exception one instance — it being stated that Captain Shelley lost, out of about sixty men, all except seven.
Capt S it seems, had been ordered to hold a certain point at all hazards, when he was completely surrounded by the enemy, and made to suffer heavily, as above stated.

The enemy finally succeeded in extricating himself from our cavalry, and proceeded on his route, but, from what we consider reliable information, he will find many obstacles in his path before he reaches his own lines Under the direction of Gen Echols and Maj Dorman, who are in that portion of the State, the roads as far out as the Sweet Springs have been effectually blockaded at a number of points, which obstructions, it is thought, will enable our cavalry, that of McCausland and Imboden, together with a force under Gen Edward Jackson, from the front, to inflict an immense amount of damage upon the enemy.

During their march through the town of Salem the enemy did not take time to molest anything, believing that our forces were close in their rear The post office and telegraph office, which are always sacked, did not receive their attention.

The enemy are represented to have with them several hundred negroes, and an incalculable amount of stolen property, including hundreds of horses, cattle, sheep, &c. They allowed nothing to impede their movements, and when any of the animals gave out they were shot down in the road, and it is said that the whole line of their march is marked with the carcasses of dead animals, in many places several together, and which, under the effect of a broiling sun, are filling the air with the most horrid effluvia.

So hard pressed have been the enemy, that, when they reached Salem, the greater portion of the men had been furnished with no rations for several days, and they are described as being in a very demoralized condition.
We trust this state of thing may continue, and that we may thus be enabled to capture the greater portion of them.

div3.head: The Travis gun.
div3.p:
--Capt Travis has exhibited in Mobile one of the guns finished by him for Gen Forrest, to which he has given the name of "the Stockton gun," but which everybody seems, very property, disposed to designate by the name of the inventor.
This elegant piece was the admiration of all who saw it. being for the first time mounted and harnessed.
It is an insignificant weight to the single horse that draws it, and can nevertheless throw 20 shots a minute into an enemy's lines at two miles distant. Capt Travis will have a public trial of the gun, after which it will be dispatched to Gen Forrest.

div3.head: A sad Incident.
div3.p:
--A wife of one of the soldiers on Sullivan's Island recently visited him in camp, and carried with her delicacies from home.
Shells had not been thrown on the Island for two or three days; but while the lady, was sitting in the midst of a group of friends the enemy opened, and the very first missile descended and exploded in her lap, killed two men around her, mortally wounding another, fore off one of her arms, her limbs, and shattered her entire frame.
Strange to say, she lingered several days in this agonize condition, and finally died in the hospital

Mrs Rose Greenhow, the lady imprisoned so long by the Lincoln Government for her Southern proclivities, is now in Parts.
She has been admitted to an interview with the Emperor.
Northern papers of Saturday, the 25th, contain some additional news of interest:

div4.head: Dispatches from Grant's Army.

opener.dateline: Headquarters Army of the Potomac, June 23, 6 A. M.

div4.p:
--Wilson's division of cavalry have moved all in the direction of the Weldon railroad.
When last heard from they had reached Station, and were tearing up the track.
The Second and Sixth Corps moored from their old position on the right towards the Weldon railroad.
Lee seems to have anticipated a movement by our left, and determined to turn our right flank.
When near the Jerusalem plankroad the Second Corps was confronted by Hills Corps, and a smart engagement ensued.
A battery of the twelfth New York Artillery was annoying the rebels, who succeeded in getting round in the flank and charged it.
The infantry support being surprised, retired, leaving four guns in the hands of the enemy; but our line of battle was soon reformed.
The men had become accustomed to Lee's new practice of acting entirely on the defensive, and must have been confused by his hold assault.
Two divisions of the Fifth Corps were within easy supporting distance on the right, and the Sixth Corps was ready for any hostilities on the left
Several charges were made by the rebels, who suffered severely.

There was heavy firing in front of the Ninth Corps about midnight.
At times the musketry broke out into regular vodeys.
The firing lasted all night.

opener.dateline: Headq'rs Army of the Potomac, June 24.

div4.p: Maj. Holt, of the First Massachusetts, is slightly wounded.
It is reported that the Seventeenth New York battery has lost four guns by being surprised.
Skirmishing was continued all last night on burled, but with what result is not yet known.

The Third Excelsior Regiment, Lieut Colonel Leonard commanding, will leave here to morrow for home, their term of service having expired.
This regiment participated in all the battles of the Peninsula, under Gen McClellan, and with the exception of Antietam, all those in which the Army of the Potomac have been engaged.

div4.head: The shelling of Petersburg.
div4.p: Under date "Front of Petersburg, June 2," the Herald's correspondent thus hazards forth the villainy of its commander

During the night Col Tidball, chief of the 2d corps artillery, having previously examined the ground in front posted several batteries at favorable points — some even in advance of the infantry skirmish line and this morning they the town.
The object of the shelling was not to destroy the city, but to show the troops, which we understood were massed in the streets of Petersburg, that we could reach them with our guns.--The enemy did not open on us with their batteries opposite our front, perhaps partly, if not wholly, for the reason that our sharpshooters are so advantageously located as to make it very inconvenient for the rebel artillerists to work their prices.
A few shots were fired at us from the rebel batteries on the heights beyond the Appomattox, and the cannonading ceased altogether

div4.head: Petersburg and Richmond.
div4.p: The sapient editor of the Herald gets up the following diatribe about the status of affairs in this section:

Since Sunday morning last there appears to have been nothing more going on between the opposing armies in front of Petersburg than desultory skirmishing, the results of which may be summed up as amounting to little or nothing, loss or gain — Active skirmishing, however, serves to develop the positions and dispositions, the strong and the weak points of the enemy, and renders if difficult for him to steat a march upon us or away from us without detection and a severe punishment.
It appears, further, that under cover of this busy skirmishing our army has been steadily working nearer and nearer the enemy's lines, until, less than a mile distant our most advanced batteries command the little city, and have commenced throwing their missiles into the heart of it.

This simply means that if the rebels persist in holding and fighting for the town, it will be knocked to pieces about their cars, and made the scene of a conflagration which will compel them to evacuate the premises.
We have reason to believe that Petersburg is of has been a sort of half way house of deposit of considerable quantities of ammunition, shot and shell, corn and beacon, clothing, shoes, &c, Intended for Lee's army, in the event of his being driven out of Richmond from the northward.
Attacked from the southside, and at Petersburg as the initial point, Lee and Beauregard have, doubtless, industriously employed the last two or three days in removing their supplies from the immediate danger of a fire against which they can find no place of insurance.

While, therefore, we may hear at any moment that Petersburg, a compact and combustible city, has been reduced to a heap of ashes (such is war) and vacated in consequence by the enemy, we do not suppose that Gen. Grant has been Idle, mean time, in reference to other and grander designs.--On the other hand, we guess that his fate conference with admiral Lee means something, and that, while apparently consenting to the alternative of a regular slege of Petersburg, he is pestering some other movement which will bring his adversary to an open field fight, or drive him back over the river behind the defences of Richmond, and thence for the nearest available road for North Carolina.
This may all be done within a few days; but it may be the work yet of several weeks.
Let our readers remember their anxieties for many days and weeks concerning Vicksburg, but that Vicksburg succumbed at last, and they will feel easy in reference to Richmond, of which Petersburg is the back door.

Stanton's dispatch to Dix says that movements are in progress in Crant's army "which are not now proper for publication" He makes a very brief mention of Huster's defeat, and limits his comments to the following:

The Richmond papers report an attack on Lynchburg by Gen. Hunter on Saturday, and that he was repulsed.
It is believed, however, that there was nothing more than a reconnaissance, and that, he was repulsed.
It is believed, however, that there was nothing more than a reconnaissance, and that, having ascertained the place to be strongly defended, Gen Hunter withdrew and is operating upon the enemy's communications at other points

div4.head: Movements in the west — Forrest again at work.
div4.p:
Forrest appears just now to be in the act of paying some attention to Sherman's line of communication.
A letter from Nashville, dated the 17th inst., says:

q.p:
The intelligence of the defeat of Sturgis by Forrest was hardly received and digested here, when intelligence came to head quarters of the District of Tennessee that Forrest was already turning his attention in this direction.
You will remember that I wrote you a short time ago to the effect that Rhody had been driven back in an effort to cross the river at Florence.
It now appears that, in conjunction with Forrest, he is again about to attempt it, and that an extensive raid, under the cruel and relentless Forrest, is about to be made on the railroad communications of Gen Sherman.
And here let me say that, though.
Forrest may be successful, and coming with a very superior force of cavalry, and this is not at all improbable, he cannot affect the status of the army in Georgia.
Already provision has been made against this anticipated trouble, and if Forrest were to tear up the roads entirely it would not deprive the army at the front of the necessaries of life and munitions of war, and force a retreat.

div4.p:
These preparations for defence had hardly been finished when the information was received that Forrest was about to move across the Tennessee and attack the defences.
The information is that Rhody is about seven miles from Decatur, while Forrest, having been repulsed in one attempt to cross at Florence, is about to attempt it at Eastport, where he has flatboats.
This information was received to date, and no details have as yet been sent in.

One of our spies yesterday returned from a trip into Dixie having gone to Fulton, Ala. Rhody was there then.
He had been with Forrest in his raid against Sturgis.
Rhody stated to this spy that Sturgis had lost two hundred prisoners, one thousand killed, and five hundred and fifty, wounded.--To account for the discrepancy existing between the killed and wounded, Rhody very coolly stated that Forrest had shot a great many of the wounded who were unable to march to Columbus, Ga.--Forrest's losses were admitted to be very large, but it was not given in numbers.
Colonel Patterson was at Courtland yesterday, in command of a regiment of four hundred and fifty men.

div4.head: The advantage of a ram at Wilmington — now Stranded blockade runners are Unloaded.
div4.p:
A letter in the New York Herald, shows how valuable an iron clad is at Wilmington, in assisting blockade running.
It says:

q.p:
On May 31 and June 1 the flagship of the westside of the squadron was at Lockwood's Folly inlet, around which are clustered all the blockaders on that side.
This point is at least nine miles distant from the bar, and any blockade runner of moderate speed could have defiantly and securely run out. On June 3 the flagship still maintained the same position as on the 1st, the Victoria and Dacotah having approached nearer to the bar, to points some seven miles in advance of the flagship

div4.p:
On this day, (Thursday, the 31) at about daylight, a two masted side wheel blockade runner, was discovered ashore at Piney Point, about four miles to the westward of Fort Fisher.
The boats of the Victoria (gunboat) were immediately dispatched and boarded her, taking off twenty nine prisoners and setting her on fire.
During this time battery Campbell, a rebel earthwork, and several flying batteries were keeping up a brink fire, against the boats of the Victoria.
The shot from the battery were just about able to reach the vessel — which proved to be the Georgians McGaw — and the firing from the light guns was short and wild.
The Dacotah now came up and fired a few shots, which the rebel batteries returned, but generally speaking fell short.
In the mean while the Victoria's boats got clear and returned, and the rebels came coolly and impudently down and put out the fire and began discharging the cargo from the McCaw.

The Dacotah signalled to the senior ship the state of affair but apparently no notice was taken, and they enjoyed the gratification of seeing the rebels unload the steamer almost under their guns.
Although the steamer was aground she had not listed, but remained perfectly upright.
The rebels brought steamers to carry away the cargo, and among others one of the rams that came out a short time since.

The ram, after loading with goods from the McCaw, and on her return trip, jokingly, and with sportive gesture, when abreast the Dacotah, fired a shell, which exploded about eight hundred yards distant. On the night of the 4th, the McCaw still preserved her position on even keel, portions of her cargo — which must have been large — plied up on the beach, steamers constantly plying between her and the Cape Fear river, where her cargo was delivered.
In this instance, it is the unanimous opinion of all who witnessed the circumstances I have narrated, that the Georgiana McCaw could have been destroyed without the slightest hazard to our vessels.
The murmurs of the officers and crews of the blockaders are, if not land, very deep So utterly indifferent and so contemptuously do the blockade runners regard our apology for a blockade, that they feel perfectly safe in running the Gannett with steamers capable, at their maximum rate, of only six knots an hour — for example, the Siren captured the other day by mere accident, her compass being out two and a half points.

Until vessels of speed are placed in a position where they can be of service, our blockade simply acts a friendly interest to the blockade runners, by enhancing the value of their contraband cargoes.
Were the matter not too serious, it would appear a good joke.
Why vessels outward bound, laden with cotton, sometimes get chased by a blockader; thereupon they commence lightening her by throwing out cotton, and I am told by good authority that the blockaders do a good business by simply picking up the cotton thus cast overboard.
As many as five hundred bales a month have been picked up.

To show the enormous profits of blockade running, a vessel has only to make one round trip successfully to pay for the value of two vessels and their cargo.
But two blockade runners of trilling value have been captured during the last moon — an interval of four weeks

div4.head: Pleasant Reunion of churches Militant — the fair of the Season.
div4.p:
A very large audience assembled on the 18th instant, at the Caroadelet Street Church, in New Orleans, to witness the ceremonies of a flag presentation, from the Methodists of New York to those of New Orleans.
The flag bear this inscription:
"New York to New Orleans greeting: from the Washington Square M E Church."
Dr Newman made the presentation speech, Judge Hammill replied and then Gen Banks was called out and spoke as follows

I am sure, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, that I should not have required the invitation with which I have been honored, had I felt that I could add aught to the eloquence of the evening.
But I confess that I feel a deep interest in the sympathy manifested by the Methodists of New York for the Methodists of New Orleans.
I remember when twenty four years ago I heard Mr Calhoun say that the churches had been severed, and that no further assurance was needed of the severance of the States.
I was glad to hear the orator of the evening say that there was no animosity or malevolence in the minds of the North to the people of the South.
It is devotion to a principle and not malignity to a State or to a people, that animates them in this unhappy war.

We are mistaken if we suppose that kindness of heart leads us one from the rule of right.--This strife can have but one end, the maintenance of the union of these states and the perpetuation of the principles on which that union is founded.

div4.head: Effects of Operation in gold.
div4.p: A Philadelphia paper, in some observations on the gold disturbance, says.

q.p:
But these gambling combinations in gold stimulate and levite combinations in flour, and beef and pork, and other necessaries of life, and in this way the people are made victims all around.
A successful "corner" in gold begets in some other operator a desire for a "corner" in beef, or butter, or mess pork, or coffee, or clover seed, or any available commodity.
Thus beef was forced up to 40 cents a pound a few weeks ago, when there was an ample supply; and thus a combination of Kindred character is trying to force up the price of mess pork, in New York now. In this way the passion for that species of gambling spreads, and the people not only have to pay the increase of price in consequence of the rise in gold, but they suffer from the extortion of all the other combinations for "corners" in the necessaries of life.
The Government, by the late act of Congress, struck a blow at the root of all these evils, by making false transactions in gold penal offences, and "that's what's the matter" over in Wall street.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p:
Wm Johnson, a negro, was executed by the Yankees before Petersburg on the 19th, having been convicted of an attempt to outrage a young lady at New Kent Court House.
A Yankee letter says:

q.p:
He was hung this morning at half past 9 o'clock in front of the Jordan House, on a hill in full view of the enemy.
A battery close by had been shelling the rebel lines, and they opened in reply, throwing a number of shells rather closer than was desirable, one of which struck George Fully, sergeant-major 10th Massachusetts, who died in a few minutes

div4.p:
When Johnson was arrested by some cavalry, just after his crime he stoutly denied his guilt and gave his name as Robert Henry Hughes, and said that he belonged to the quartermaster's department.
After being sentenced, however, he admitted his guilt and gave his true name, and confessed that he enlisted in Baltimore on the 23d of March in the 23d U. S. infantry, was twenty-three years of age, and had deserted.
He said his punishment was just, and he hoped others would take warning by his fate.

div3.head: and Recapture of a prisoner.
div3.p:
Some days since, a man named Sidney Jeffries, halling from Baltimore, was committed to Castle Thunder, but hardly had be been fairly installed before he effected a temporary escape.
When ushered into the large room in which the majority of the prisoners are confined he espied on the floor a half sheet of letter paper.
This be took up, and rolling it over kept it in one of his hands, and deliberately walked by the sentinels, gained the street, and was turning up 19th street to Main, when he was met by detective Caphart, who happened to know him, and again taken back to prison, where he was kept in a cell for a short time, until he was released and placed with the other prisoners upon his promise to behave better for the future.
It seems that the guards on duty at the time were novices in the business, and therefore permitted Jeffries to pass out of the building under the impression that he was one of the officials.

div3.head: Acquittal of Dr. McClure.
div3.p:
--In Judge Halyburton's Court yesterday Dr. W McClure, the embalmer, was arraigned for trial on an indictment charging him with a misdemeanor and attempting to bribe Confederate detectives.
When the case was called the counsel for the accused, Messrs R T Daniel and F W Hoblitzell, moved that the indictment be quashed, which was accordingly done by the Judge, and Maclure thereupon discharged.
The law makes it a penal offence to offer a bribe to a judge or any person interested in the trial of a cause; but to attempt to buy order a Confederate detective, or other police officer, is not considered a crime.
The long confinement which Maclure has endured has greatly reduced him in flesh, (though at best he was by no means very robust,) and on the street after his acquittal yesterday he was scarcely recognized by his most intimate acquaintances.

div3.head: Bagus D
div3.p:
--On Monday night three men visited the house of Mr. Schwartz, a butcher living below Rockets, and finding him absent from home, represented themselves as Confederate detectives, who had been sent there to search for forged passports.
In the absence of Mr. S., his wife protested that no such documents were secreted about the house, but the fellows insisted on searching, and finding in a trunk about $250 in gold, $300 in silver, and $500 in greenbacks, they took it in charge, and stated to her that they had been directed a so to take charge of any money found about her house.
When they were about leaving the premises, with the trunk containing the money in their hands, Mrs. S. was informed that if she called at General Gardner's (formerly General Winder's) office at nine o'clock the next (yesterday) morning, she would learn what disposition had been made of her funds.
Accordingly Mrs. Schwartz called at the appointed hour, but it is needless to say that the trunk and contents had not been carried there, nor were the men ever engaged in the Confederate detective service.

div3.p: --The following is a report of yesterday's proceedings.

Maria Canary was charged with stealing one calico dress, valued at $80, the property of Mrs. Mary E. Tuck.
Some two months since, while Mrs. T. was confined to her bed from sickness, Mrs. Canary came to her house and desired to purchase a dress, being hard up for money, she was told that she could have it for $80, but deeming the price too high, Mrs C. would not take it, and left the house.
A few days after this dress was stolen, and nothing was heard of it till last Sunday, when the accused was seen with it on in the street.
Mrs. Canary stated that she bought it from a negro woman, who told her she was authorized by her mistress to sell it. This Mrs. Tuck denied.
The Mayor remanded the accused for examination before the Hustings Court.

Wm. Jackson, a free negro boy, charged with stealing about fifty dollars in notes, twenty five cents in silver, and a silver watch, valued at $200, from Minerva Jackson, a free woman, was ordered to be whipped.
A big, Jolly old black woman, who came to the witness stand pulling and blowing as if she was propelled by steam, testified that Bill Jackson acknowledged stealing the money and watch from her daughter Minerva's trunk, and said that he had spent some of the funds, but what was left of it he had given to his mother; the watch was at his aunt's. div3.p:
--The situation is unchanged.

div3.p: A Northern journal asserts that the only reason the Western troops have been more successful than the Northern in this war is that Gen. Grant was their commander.

It is idle to expect in any Northern newspaper the language of reason, sobriety, or truth.
The Western troops may not be braver or more resolute than the Northern, but they are hardier, more accustomed to the use of arms, and withal have a strong admixture of Southern blood.
Many of the original setters of Illinois, Indiana, and Southern Ohio, were emigrants from the Southern States Kentucky and some portions of Tennessee have furnished the United States the best troops of its Western army.
But not all these facts combined account for the successes of the Western army.
Those successes were the result of an immense preponderance of numbers, and, in some instances, of our own mismanagement.
Certainly, it was not the generalship of Grant to which the credit is due. He was whipped repeatedly there, and never achieved a success except by enormous odds and by our own palpable blunders.

We have no desire to detract from his military character.
He is brimful of bovine energy, but his brains are not equal to his pluck.
Even his pluck, so far as we have any proof, consist in a readiness to have his men slaughtered rather than expose himself to personal permit.
We hear of him smoking, we hear of him whetting; we hear of his stereotyped order, "Send the men in," but we do not hear of his going in himself.
This is no impeachment, we confess, of his courage.
Nor is it the duty of a commander in chief to expose himself to danger; but when pluck is claimed as his distinguishing quality, we deny that the exposure of other men to danger affords any proof of it. In military genius there is no comparison between Grant and McClellan.
The boasted achievement of transferring his army from the north to the south bank of the James might have been accomplished in the beginning of his campaign without the loss of a single life.
He might have come at once to McClellan's old position and crossed the river, or he might have landed on the Southside and reached Petersburg without difficulty.
Instead of that, he came upon a line which he proclaimed he would hold if it took him all summer, and sacrificed seventy-five or a hundred thousand men to reach a point which he might have reached without expending a drop of blood.
If he had a hundred thousand men to spare why not send them to Butler, while he pressed Lee on the Rapidan ? And finally, if the Western army succeeded because it had Ulysses S. Grant at its head, why has not the Northern army succeeded under the same chieftainship ? To assume its success before it has attained its object is in keeping with the boastfulness of a people who take cities one day in newspapers and eat their own words the next.

div3.head: Benevolent enemies.
div3.p:
If ever there has been a fixed and universal opinion in the North on any one subject, it is that slave labor is unprofitable, or, in their choice vernacular, that it "doesn't pay." However they may have differed at one time upon the abolition question, there never was any difference about the greater cheapness of free labor.
The same economical ideas that led to the extinguishment of serfdom in Europe were applied with an air of greater plausibility to the slave labor of the Southern States.
It was alone because negro slavery was unprofitable that it was abolished in the Northern States, and no one there was able to see why it should not be equally valueless in the Southern States, especially those not engaged in cotton growing.
They maintained that one white man could do the work of three negroes; that "the black pigs of the Virginia litter were draining her dry," that but for slavery Virginia would be one of the wealthiest and greatest of communities.
The slaves were described as wasteful, improvident, filthy, an incubus upon the resources and growth of the white population.

Keeping in mind this universal Northern conviction, we must of course recognise their wholesale plunder of slaves in this war as a benevolent effort to relieve us of a great nuisance ! We wonder they have not put it themselves upon that ground, and claimed to be our greatest benefactors ! Finding that we could not be induced by persuasion and reasoning to do justice to our own interests, they are foreing us to our own good by sword and plunder ! Earnest and energetic philanthropists, they will permit no community to go to destruction its own way ! They take away our negroes in order to relieve the State from a heavy drag upon its energies and prosperity.
Is it not wonderful that we are ungrateful to such benefactors ? We cling to our "incubus" as closely as ever; we are determined not to give it up; but we have a passion still stronger than our predilection for slavery.--It is, strange to say, our detestation of the philanthropical pedlars who are endeavoring to swindle us out of our property.
If every negro in the State were stolen, we should only detest the idea of Yankee domination the more.
We would rather lose all our slaves than be slaves to them.
It may suit the purposes of the North to represent the Southern defence to the world as a war for slavery.
It is no such thing.
It is a war for our own liberties and independence.

div3.head: Maximilian.
div3.p: The Proclamation of Maximilian, upon entering Mexico, beginneth after this wise: "Mexicans, you have desired to have you," &c. This is probably a wrong translation "Mexicans, I have desired to have you," is doubtlessly the true rendering.

It is difficult to understand the language of kings and potentates, even when they speak in one's own tongue; much more when their words are translated.
Resides, European Emperors are a novelty on this continent.
We make all allowance, therefore, for the curious assertion put in the mouth of Maximilian.
He may have said it, however; but our own interpretation gives his meaning, if not his words.
Possibly the Mexicans may wish to "have him," and there are others besides Mexicans who entertain a similar desire.
If the United States could once overrun the South, they would have Maximilian and his Empire in six months after that event.

div3.head: Retaliation.
div3.p:
The coinsures which have been visited upon the Confederate Government for steadily refusing to hoist the black flag, are, it seems to us, hasty and undeserved. --Whilst retaliation is right, and a bounden duty, wherever the facts that call for it can be satisfactorily established, it is not so easy to establish the facts in each individual allegation, nor to punish the wrong doer even when the facts are established.
As to hoisting the black flag, that is easier said than done.
Let any man calmly reflect upon the probable consequences of hoisting the black flag, and he will scarcely be in a humor to condemn the President, even on the score of policy, for adhering as long as possible to the laws of civilized warfare.
Moreover, in the language attributed to General Lee, "we should be governed not so much by what our enemies deserve, as by what is due to ourselves." Can any man suppose that the President is less sensitive than any one else to the atrocities committed by the Vanndale, or that if it were right and expedient to hoist the black flag, he would hesitate to recommend it?
Who has as much interest as himself in pursuing that course which is best for the public good ?

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p:
Killed in action on Gatnes's farm, near Richmond, an the 3d of June, 1861, private William F. Benda company K, 47th Virginia regiment, aged 23 years, son of Albert C, and Lucy A. Bendall, of Caroline county.
Va.

Thus has perished in manhood's early bloom an other noble, pure and gallant spirit, beloved by the others and men of his company and all who knew him. Oh, who can tell the grief of that mother when the sad news reached her ears that her boy was killed.
But comfort her to know that he felt at his post, in a glorious cause, hatting for his home and loved ones and all that is worth living for.

Poor Billy how he will be missed.
He has left an aching void in our grieved hearts which this world can never fill.
But this cruel war has carried many a home.
Fond mother, weep not for thy boy, but strive to meet him in that land where we hope he has gone, and where there will be no more war, and no more will the booming of cannon or the rear of musketry arouse thee.--Thou hast fought thy last battle.

Poor Billy enlisted in the defence of his country shortly after the commencement of the war. He was a good soldier, participated in several struggles, and was wounded in the battle of Chancel lorsville in May, 1863, but recovered and returned to his command where he faithfully discharged his duties up to the time he was struck by the fatal ball fro the enemy's cannon.

He leaves a father, mother, two sisters and three brothers, besides a large circle of friends and relatives, to mourn their loss.
But we hope our loss is his gain.
Let us alive to meet him where sickness and sorrow, pain and death are felt no more.

lg.l: Pale eve will weep soft dews above
The spot as from a mother's love,
And birds for him will mourning sing,
While o'er his grave sweet flowers will spring.
Green be the turf above thee,
Friend of thy better days,
None knew thee but to love thee,
None named thee but to praise.

div3.p:
It is respectfully suggested to Gov Smith that he would make some arrangement by which the 19th regiment, commanded by Col Evans, and the 1st, commanded by Col Danforth, should be placed under the command of one superior officer.
The writer has no interest whatever in the arrangement suggested, except for the public good and the benefit of the officers and men in these regiments, both of which, he thinks, would be thereby promoted.

Both regiments being under the direction of an officer of a rank superior to that of Colonel, the duties of each regiment, it seems to the writer, would be more certain of being equally apportioned.
The regiments are suppose to be on an equal footing, and I am sure that the men in both are ready cheerfully to perform their fair share of duty.
This cannot always be done while each regiment is acting independently of the other.

As an illustration of this, the 19th regiment have almost to the last man, been performing responsible guard duty constantly, without relief, for several days.
The 1st regiment, at the end of that time, very readily came to their relief, and are now doing the same heavy duty.

In this instance nearly all the men of each regiment are alternately kept on guard until worn out, whereas, if the change were made which is here suggested, under one directing head, the business could be systematized and the duties judiciously distributed, so as to add much to the comfort of the officers and men, as well as to the efficiency of the service they render.

If the Governor, for these and other good reasons, should see fit to make the arrangement suggested, I hope be would confer the appointment on Col Evane, as he is qualified, in all respects for the position, being a gentleman of most amiable disposition, always anxious to promote the interest and comfort of his and as an officer thoroughly informed and competent to perform its duties.
Indeed, the date of his commission would entitle him to the promotion if the change should be made

div3.head: An appeal to the people of the Confederate States
div3.p:
--The Directors of the Young Men's Christian Association of Richmond respectfully, but earnestly, submit to the benevolent and the patriotic throughout the Confederate States an appeal in behalf of the soldiers' families in this city.
Since the commencement of the war Richmond has been a refuge for these who have been driven from their homes by our ruthless enemies.
Thousands of helpless woman and children, not from the devastated counties of Virginia alone, but from nearly every State of the Confederacy, have sought an asylum in our midst.
Our citizens have been appealed to in numberless instances to relieve the sick and wounded soldiers, to furnish shoes and clothing for saluters in the field and hospital, and to afford food and shelter for their suffering families, and nobly have they, in the great majority of instances, responded to every appeal.

The supplies of provisions in the city at this time are so reduced, and the difficulties of obtaining others by ordinary means so numerous and great, that the funds contributed for the relief of the poor can accomplish but little in purchasing the necessaries of life.

In a written report from the Clothing Burman it appears that there are more than three thousand females in this city who are seeking employment from the Government in vain, and that those who obtain work are not fully employed.
The wages received for their work will not enable these poor women to procure a sufficiency of the plainest food for themselves and children.
Without assistance, then, from the city and country generally, many instances of actual starvation must have occurred.
Our City Council has made most liberal appropriations for the purchase of supplies, both for gratuitous distribution and for sale at cost; but the agents employed for the purpose have not been able to procure the quantity of provisions required.

Under these circumstances we feel that it is our duty to appeal to our fellow citizens throughout the Confederate States to forward, without delay, contributions of money and supplies to the Army Committee of this association.
Since the commencement of the war this Committee has labored zealously and faithfully for the temporal and spiritual welfare of our soldiers and their families and for the success of our glorious cause.
Let those soldiers not be discouraged now, upon the eve of our severest, and, as we trust, our last and most glorious campaign, for want of the generous sympathy and support of their friends at home.

Shipments made to Roger Martin, Superintendent, or Wm P Munford, Chairman of the Army Committee, will be promptly attended to. And in accordance with a special agreement made with the Superintendent of the Southern Express Company; all express charges will be paid by them at Richmond.
Contributions of money should also be sent to these gentlemen.

--For the balance of the year, a good cook washer and ironer.
Apply to Dr Joynos, Franklin street, above 7th, or to N G Turnley, at Spencer & Venable's, Cary street, below 12th.

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--A likely young woman for the balance of the year.
Has had some experience as a house girl.

closer.signed: Officer cor Wall and Franklin sts.

div3.head: For hire
div3.p: --Several girls, between 16 and 20 years of age. Apply to Mrs Wm Allen, on Leigh street, between 7th and 8th.

div3.head: 200 dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to us of William Shepard, who ran away from our bakery on Thursday night last.
He is about 5 feet 6 inches high, dark ginger bread color, stout built, and talks rather slow.

div3.head: 200 dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid by for the apprehension and confinement any of a negro man named Rely, who ran away from Wm & Branton, in Amelia county.
Said negro was purchased by said Branton of R. H. Norvell, in Richmond.
Address
div3.closer:
John J Gills,
Jetersville P O, Amelia, Va. je 23--2tau 3w*

div3.head: 25 dollars reward
div3.p:
--Each will be paid for the apprehension of Reuben, Jerry, three slaves employed by the Va Central Railroad Company, and supposed to be in the city.
taken out of the city the reward will be doubled-- Jerry has a tear on his upper lip, and the color of all is black.

div3.head: 500 dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for its apprehension and confinement so I can get him, (if out of the State, and $250 if in the State,) of my man Chelsy.
Chelsy is about 5 feet 10 inches high, brown color, rather quite intelligent, weighs about 165 or and is a first rate carpenter.
div3.closer:
Henry Carrington,
Drake's Branch Post Office,
Charlotte county, Va. je 22--3taw2w
